channel.title: BBC News
channel.copyright: Copyright: (C) British Broadcasting Corporation, see https://www.bbc.co.uk/usingthebbc/terms-of-use/#15metadataandrssfeeds for terms and conditions of reuse.

item.title: Women warned weight-loss jabs may affect the pill
item.description: Women should use the most effective contraception to avoid pregnancy while taking 'skinny jabs', the drugs regulator says.

item.title: Greater awareness not more cases behind ADHD surge, study suggests
item.description: Study found no evidence of significant rise with jump in demand for help down to under-diagnosis.

item.title: First bacteria we ever meet can keep us out of hospital
item.description: For the first time, scientists show how our microbiome forms affects the risk of infection.

item.title: Police investigate heart deaths at NHS hospital
item.description: Patients who died at Castle Hill Hospital near Hull may have suffered avoidable harm, documents suggest.

item.title: Syphilis and drug-resistant gonorrhoea increasing
item.description: Experts say the gonorrhoea figures are a worry. although the actual number of drug-resistant cases is low.

item.title: Exercise improves colon cancer survival, major study shows
item.description: Risk of dying was cut by a third after colon cancer patients dialled up exercise levels.

item.title: Manslaughter case launched into Nottingham baby deaths
item.description: A corporate manslaughter investigation has been opened by police as a major review continues.

item.title: Pharmacists warn drug shortage affecting cancer patients
item.description: Some patients are skipping meals due to a shortage of Creon, says a pharmacy association.

item.title: Disposable vape ban begins - but will it have an impact?
item.description: Retailers will no longer be able to sell single-use vapes as new laws come into force across the UK.

item.title: People say cola and fries are helping their migraines - but there's a twist
item.description: Migraines are one of the most complex neurological disorders. What is the science behind the latest hack?

item.title: 'My life was saved by a stranger on the other side of the world'
item.description: An Australian man meets his stem-cell donor for the first time after travelling to the UK.

item.title: How 'laughing gas' became a deadly - but legal - American addiction
item.description: Nitrous oxide overdoses have increased in the US, but the substance is still legal as a "culinary product".

item.title: Streeting urges doctors to vote no in strike ballot
item.description: Resident doctors unhappy with 5.4% pay rise with union warning strikes in England could return.

item.title: NHS Scotland waits of more than two years on the rise
item.description: New figures show waiting lists have an growing number of two-year waits for appointments and treatment.

item.title: Patients from Nottingham killer's NHS trust carried out stabbings weeks before attack
item.description: Two men under the care of the same NHS trust as Valdo Calocane carried out stabbings weeks before the Nottingham attacks.

item.title: Cross-sex hormones for under 18s could be restricted or banned
item.description: The government is "actively reviewing" private prescriptions of cross-sex hormones for under-18s, the High Court hears.

item.title: Women with dense breasts should have extra NHS cancer scans, researchers say
item.description: Additional scans better tailored to spotting cancer in dense breasts could treble detection rates.

item.title: Scientists propose novel way of treating mosquitoes for malaria
item.description: Normally the insects are targeted with insecticide, but US researchers say anti-malaria drugs absorbed through their legs can stop them spreading disease.

item.title: West Nile virus detected in UK mosquitoes for first time
item.description: A UK Health Security Agency spokesperson said the risk to the general public is "very low".

item.title: World-first gonorrhoea vaccine launched by NHS England as infections soar
item.description: The treatment will be offered to those most at risk from August after a record number of cases.

item.title: Infected blood victims call for faster compensation
item.description: Diana Johnson MP, who has campaigned with victims, tells BBC slow progress is "disappointing".

item.title: Can AI therapists really be an alternative to human help?
item.description: With NHS mental health waitlists at record highs, are chatbots a possible solution?

item.title: For, against, undecided: Three GPs give their views on assisted dying
item.description: GPs from different areas of England tell us how they feel about plans to legalise assisted dying.

item.title: Government has no clear plan for NHS England abolition, say MPs
item.description: Cross-party group of MPs say move is causing uncertainty at time when NHS is under huge pressure.

item.title: Child obesity clinics seeing BMIs over 50
item.description: Many are from the most deprived areas, and a significant number are neurodivergent or have other health conditions, a study says.

item.title: Charity boss slams 'reprehensible' health trusts
item.description: NHS trusts "try to stop" coroners issuing Prevention of Future Death reports, an inquiry hears.

item.title: Care providers say overseas worker crackdown 'short-sighted'
item.description: Many care workers say it is a rewarding job, so the task is how to get more people in the UK to apply.

item.title: Doctor accused of falsifying artificial mesh records
item.description: Tony Dixon was suspended after mesh surgery was found to have caused harm to hundreds of patients.

item.title: The Covid Inquiry Podcast: 'I wasn't the decision maker'
item.description: The Inquiry hears from the lead of the test and trace unit

item.title: Cash to isolate 'would have cut Covid deaths'
item.description: Baroness Dido Harding tells Covid inquiry Rishi Sunak blocked higher support payments.

item.title: Johnson wanted tighter Covid rules, inquiry hears
item.description: In his diaries, Lord Vallance wrote that ex-PM thought rules were not ruthless enough.

item.title: Hancock criticises 'wholly naive' Covid inquiry
item.description: The former health secretary was giving evidence about medical equipment deals during the pandemic.

item.title: Mone accuses Covid inquiry of 'cover-up'
item.description: She says husband Doug Barrowman and her are targets of a "politically motivated witch hunt".

item.title: Michael Gove denies trying to circumvent Dyson ventilator checks
item.description: Former cabinet minister says it would be ludicrous to suggest he tried to shortcut safety checks in the pandemic.

item.title: How does the Covid inquiry work?
item.description: The inquiry has heard from politicians, civil servants, public health experts and bereaved families.

item.title: Michelle Mone-linked PPE firm evidence to be heard in private
item.description: Covid inquiry says hearings into the firm, led by Michelle Mone's husband, must be held in closed session.

item.title: Large UK-wide pandemic preparedness tests planned this year
item.description: The stress test will involve thousands of people to help the UK prepare for potential future threats.

item.title: Families failed by Covid jabs tell inquiry of pain
item.description: They said there was no support after the death and harm suffered by their loved ones.

item.title: NHS hours from PPE running out in Covid - Hancock
item.description: Former health secretary tells inquiry some healthcare settings did run out - "and it was awful".

item.title: Covid inquiry told Treasury blocked NHS bed request
item.description: NHS England chief executive Amanda Pritchard says the decision, in July 2020, was very disappointing.

item.title: Covid inquiry told top NHS doctor was terrified
item.description: Sir Stephen Powis says points-based tool was drawn up should need to prioritise patients have arisen.

item.title: How close were hospitals to collapse in Covid?
item.description: The Covid inquiry restarts its live hearings this week, after senior staff in the NHS revealed just how close some hospitals were to collapse

item.title: Covid inquiry told of trust do-not-resuscitate rule
item.description: Patients' families were “horrified but not surprised” when told the blanket policy had been in place.

item.title: We were not treated as parents, Covid inquiry told
item.description: Mum of premature twins says rigid restrictions on birthing wards during Covid were traumatic.

item.title: Covid ambulance crews faced 'crucial PPE delays'
item.description: Crews say they faced crucial delays trying to save dying patients because of the time it took to put on equipment.

item.title: Covid was like a daily terror attack, doctor tells inquiry
item.description: Covid inquiry hears harrowing testimony from ex-adviser in emergency preparedness at NHS England.

item.title: Covid inquiry rejects clinicians’ anonymity plea
item.description: The UK Health Security Agency argued naming the junior officials could put them at risk of abuse.

item.title: Why are disposable vapes being banned and how harmful is vaping?
item.description: It will be illegal to sell or supply disposable vapes from 1 June 2025.

item.title: Labour's plan for benefits throws up a bigger dilemma
item.description: The debate has sparked a wider dilemma about the broader purpose of welfare

item.title: First place in British Isles set to approve right to die
item.description: Laws in the Isle of Man to let terminally ill adults end their own lives are in the last stages of debate.

item.title: Generation K: The disturbing rise of ketamine abuse among young people
item.description: Increasing numbers of young people are using the drug, experts say. The health impacts can be catastrophic.

item.title: Assisted dying bill: What is in proposed law?
item.description: The proposed law would allow some terminally ill adults to end their own lives. But there are requirements.

item.title: 'My first cervical screening was over before I knew it'
item.description: The BBC speaks to six people about their first cervical screening, and what they wish they'd known beforehand.

item.title: Is the system letting down people who were harmed by Covid vaccines?
item.description: People affected by rare blood clots say they feel they have been airbrushed out of the pandemic.

item.title: How will weight-loss drugs change our relationship with food?
item.description: The rise of these treatments has major implications for how we think about obesity, says James Gallagher.

item.title: NHS needs better plan around weight loss jabs, warn experts
item.description: Experts call for an urgent review of obesity treatment services amid booming demand for weight loss jabs.

item.title: How many of us will end up being diagnosed with ADHD?
item.description: Experts suggest that the number of people with ADHD is actually going to remain steady.

item.title: The junior doctors' strikes may be over. But is trouble ahead?
item.description: The end of the pay dispute sounded too good to be true. And now some are wondering if it might be.

item.title: Why we might never know the truth about ultra-processed foods
item.description: Experts can’t agree how exactly they affect us and it’s not clear that science will give us an answer.

item.title: Are weight-loss injections the answer to obesity?
item.description: The appeal is clear - but should we be turning to appetite-suppressing injections?

item.title: Abortion laws are Victorian era, says grieving mum
item.description: Elen Hughes, who lost her son Danial at 37-and-a-half weeks, says police guidance is "terrible".

item.title: 'I had to leave my baby and felt like a prisoner in hospital'
item.description: Mothers with serious mental health problems are separated from their babies in Northern Ireland, unlike the rest of the UK.

item.title: 'I'm tackling my diabetes risk for my grandson'
item.description: NHS Sussex urges people to take action as Type 2 diabetes cases rise across the county.

item.title: Hopes of parenthood crushed after IVF embryos destroyed in Israel's Gaza offensive
item.description: Couples in Gaza using IVF to help them conceive “left with nothing” after 4,000 embryos at an IVF clinic were destroyed.

item.title: NHS Scotland waits of more than two years on the rise
item.description: New figures show waiting lists have an growing number of two-year waits for appointments and treatment.

item.title: New nature health scheme aims to boost well-being
item.description: The RSPB, which helped draw up the scheme, says it has been a success in other parts of the UK.

item.title: Horse charity calls on NHS to fund equine services
item.description: Horses for Wellbeing says the funding would see children get help before they "hit crisis point".

item.title: Nature festival launched at national Park
item.description: Events included wildlife walks, art sessions and the chance to meet an Exmoor pony.

item.title: Helping on the farm reaps mental health benefits
item.description: Farm Care has "seen an impact" on youngsters' mental health on east Surrey farms.

item.title: Rugby star part of campaign to better mental health
item.description: The England fly-half will be at the University of Surrey promoting a new set of wellbeing exercises.

item.title: Inside Health
item.description: Drs Chris and Xand are on a mission to help us take better care of ourselves.

item.title: Inside Health
item.description: James explores the science of a sweet tooth and then gets tips on how to brush like a pro.

item.title: Inside Health
item.description: James Gallagher and the panel consider if an assisted death can guarantee a peaceful end.

item.title: Inside Health
item.description: James Gallagher and the panel discuss the safeguarding implications of the proposed bill

item.title: The Inquiry
item.description: Why fungal diseases are becoming more dangerous to human health
